overview: 3 John commends Gaius for showing hospitality to traveling missionaries and rebukes Diotrephes who selfishly rejected them. It shows the importance of supporting gospel workers.

verses.text: I have no greater joy than to hear that my children are walking in the truth.
Beloved, do not imitate evil but imitate good. Whoever does good is from God; whoever does evil has not seen God.

passages.title: Hospitality for Truth
passages.summary: Supporting traveling missionaries makes us 'fellow workers for the truth'—hospitality serves the gospel.

facts.text: 3 John is one of the shortest books in the Bible, a personal letter to one individual named Gaius.
Diotrephes 'loves to be first' and refuses to welcome the brothers—a warning against selfish church leadership.
The contrast between Gaius and Diotrephes shows what hospitality should and shouldn't look like.

figures.name: John
figures.description: The elder commending and correcting, promising to visit and deal with the situation personally.

figures.name: Gaius
figures.description: A faithful believer commended for generously hosting traveling missionaries, even strangers.

figures.name: Diotrephes
figures.description: A self-promoting leader who rejected John's authority and refused hospitality to traveling teachers.

figures.name: Demetrius
figures.description: Commended by everyone, by the truth itself, and by John—a model of good reputation.

videos.title: 1-3 John Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores John's three letters together.
